title: How to Make Mulberry Cobbler

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.description: Lightly grease an 8 in (20 cm) square baking dish, then set it aside.

steps.headline: Toss the mulberries with the butter and lemon juice.
steps.description: Place  3½ cups (490 g) of mulberries into a large bowl. Add ¼ cup (55 g) of melted, unsalted butter and ½ teaspoon of lemon juice. Gently toss the 3 ingredients together until the mulberries are evenly coated with butter and lemon juice. ¼ cup (55 g) of butter is equal to about half a stick of a butter. Refer to the tablespoon marks printed on the wrapper. If the bowl is too small to toss the berries, you can gently stir the mixture with a rubber spatula. Be careful not to crush the berries. Rinse the mulberries first, then trim off the stems.

steps.headline: Mix the brown sugar and flour in a new bowl, then add it to the berries.
steps.description: Place 1 to 2 tablespoons (12.5 to 25 g) of brown sugar into a small bowl, then add 2 tablespoons (15 g) of all-purpose flour. Stir the 2 together until they are evenly combined. Sprinkle the mixture evenly across the berries, then stir it in with a rubber spatula. How much sugar you add is up to you. Keep in mind that mulberries are sweeter than most other berries, so 1 tablespoon might be enough. Be careful while doing this so that you don't accidentally crush the berries.

steps.headline: Spread the berries across the bottom of the greased 8 in (20 cm) pan.
steps.description: Pour the berry filling into your prepared pan, then use your rubber spatula to help spread them evenly across the bottom.

steps.headline: Mix the granulated sugar, flour, salt, baking powder, and milk.
steps.description: Pour 1 cup (225 g) of granulated sugar into a clean bowl. Add ¾ cup (75 g) of all-purpose flour, ¼ teaspoon of salt, and 2 teaspoons of baking powder. Whisk them together, then stir in ⁄4 cup (180 mL) of milk. You can mix everything together all at once, but it is easier to mix the dry ingredients together first before adding the wet. Mix the batter well enough so that the texture is consistent. Don't worry if there are some clumps.

steps.headline: Spoon the batter over the berry filling in large clumps.
steps.description: You won't be able to pour the batter like you would cake batter. Instead, use a soup ladle to scoop the batter up and drop it by the spoonfuls over the berries. Don't worry if you can't cover the berries evenly. Most cobblers have gaps between the lumps of batter. This is part of the aesthetic.

steps.headline: Bake the cobbler until it turns golden brown, about 40 minutes.
steps.description: The cobbler is ready when the topping turns golden brown, and the berries release their juice and bubble. If the cobbler isn't ready after 40 minutes, keep checking on it every 5 minutes. Cobblers can sometimes take up to 1 hour to bake.

steps.headline: Let the cobbler cool for 10 to 15 minutes, then serve it.
steps.description: Because there is no crust, you won't be able to remove the cobbler from the pan. Instead, use a metal spatula to cut and serve the cobbler. You can enjoy the cobbler hot or chilled. If you want to serve the cobbler chilled, let it reach room temperature first, then tuck it into the fridge for 1 to 2 hours. For extra flavor, serve it with some vanilla ice cream or whipped cream. Cover any leftovers with foil, then store them in the fridge for up to 4 or 5 days.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 375 °F (191 °C).
steps.description: Lightly coat a 2  qt (1.9 L) baking dish with butter or cooking spray, then set it aside.

steps.headline: Mix the mulberries, peaches, lemon juice, and lemon zest.
steps.description: Place 4 cups (560 g) of mulberries into a large bowl. Add 2 cups (450 g) of peeled and chopped peaches, 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of lemon juice, and 1 teaspoon of finely-grated lemon zest. Gently stir everything together with a rubber spatula. Be sure to rinse the mulberries ahead of time and to trim off the stems.

steps.headline: Combine the sugar and flour in a separate bowl.
steps.description: Pour ⅓ cup (75 g) of granulated sugar into a small bowl. Add 1 tablespoon (7.5 g) of all-purpose flour, then stir them together with a whisk. Mulberries tend to be very sweet. If you want something less sweet, use a little less sugar. Keep in mind that the lemon juice will help cut the sweetness.

steps.headline: Add the sugar to the mulberries, then scoop it into the baking dish.
steps.description: Sprinkle the sugar mixture evenly over the mulberry mixture, then stir everything together once more with a rubber spatula. Pour the filling into a lightly greased 2  qt (1.9 L) baking dish. Use your rubber spatula to spread the filling evenly across the bottom of the baking dish.

steps.headline: Mix the flour, sugar, baking powder, rosemary, and salt in a new bowl.
steps.description: Pour 1¼ cups (125 g) of all-purpose flour into a large, clean bowl. Add ⅓ cup (75 g) of granulated sugar, 2 teaspoons of baking powder, and ½ heaping teaspoon of finely-chopped fresh rosemary. Top it off with ¼ teaspoon of salt, then give the mixture a brief stir. You can use the same bowl that you used to mix the filling in, but make sure that you wash and dry it first.

steps.headline: Whisk the egg, buttermilk, and vanilla in a separate bowl.
steps.description: Crack open 1 egg into a medium-sized bowl. Add ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of buttermilk, 6 tablespoons (85 g) of unsalted butter, and ½ teaspoon of vanilla extract. Stir everything together with a whisk until they combine. 6 tablespoons (85 g) of butter is roughly equal to ¾ of a stick. Use the tablespoon markings on the wrapper as a guide. Measure and melt the butter ahead of time. Allow it to cool to room temperature, but don't wait for it to solidify.

steps.headline: Fold the egg mixture into the flour mixture.
steps.description: Pour the egg mixture into the flour mixture. Gently stir the 2 together with your rubber spatula, scraping the bottom and sides of the bowl often. Keep mixing until the color and texture of the dough is consistent. Be careful not to overmix the dough; there will be some clumps, which is fine.

steps.headline: Scoop the dough over the filling.
steps.description: You can't pour the dough like cake batter, so use a soup ladle or a large spoon to scoop it up and plop it onto the berry filling. There will be some gaps between the clumps of dough, which is typical for cobblers. For more texture, sprinkle some sugar over the dough. For a more savory treat, use salt instead, or a combination of both.

steps.headline: Bake the cobbler for 35 minutes.
steps.description: It is ready if you poke a toothpick into the topping and it comes out clean. If the toothpick does not come out clean, bake the cobbler for another 5 minutes or so.

steps.headline: Serve the cobbler warm or at room temperature.
steps.description: You can also chill it in the fridge for a more refreshing treat. For extra flavor, add some whipped cream or ice cream. If you have any cobbler leftover, cover the dish with foil, then put it into the fridge. Eat it within 4 to 5 days.
